articles.headline: Judge Rejects Teacher Tenure for California
articles.snippet: The decision handed teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case to overturn laws governing how teachers are hired and fired and is expected to set off similar fights across the nation.
articles.abstract: The decision handed teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case to overturn laws governing how teachers are hired and fired and is expected to set off similar fights across the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A California judge ruled Tuesday that teacher tenure laws deprived students of their right to an education under the State Constitution and violated their civil rights. The decision hands teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case, one that could radically alter how California teachers are hired and fired and prompt challenges to tenure laws in other states.

articles.headline: Hong Kong Regulators Tense About China Loans
articles.snippet: A surge in lending to Chinese companies is leading Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.
articles.abstract: A surge in lending to Chinese companies is leading Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | A surge in business loans to the slowing mainland Chinese economy has prompted Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.

articles.headline: A Bellwether for London Realty
articles.snippet: As the HSBC tower has changed hands in recent years, it has become an emblem of the boom-bust-boom cycle of London’s commercial property market.
articles.abstract: As the HSBC tower has changed hands in recent years, it has become an emblem of the boom-bust-boom cycle of London’s commercial property market.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the global bank HSBC sold its London headquarters tower to a Spanish buyer in spring 2007, at the height of the credit and property boom, the deal was the single largest real estate transaction in British history.

articles.headline: Eric Cantor Defeated by David Brat, Tea Party Challenger, in G.O.P. Primary Upset
articles.snippet: In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, Mr. Cantor, the House majority leader, was soundly defeated by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed candidate.
articles.abstract: In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, Mr. Cantor, the House majority leader, was soundly defeated by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, was soundly defeated on Tuesday by a Tea Party-backed economics professor who had hammered him for being insufficiently conservative.

articles.headline: One Key to Success: A Belief in a Future
articles.snippet: A program for teenage boys in Chicago makes a contribution to the battle against entrenched income inequality.
articles.abstract: A program for teenage boys in Chicago makes a contribution to the battle against entrenched income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tim Jackson’s job is to convince young people that they have a stake in the future.

articles.headline: Microsoft Protests Order to Disclose Email Stored Abroad
articles.snippet: The objection to hand over email stored in an Irish data center is believed to be the first time a corporation has challenged a domestic search warrant seeking digital information overseas.
articles.abstract: The objection to hand over email stored in an Irish data center is believed to be the first time a corporation has challenged a domestic search warrant seeking digital information overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customer’s email stored in a data center in Ireland.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Rule May Alter Cheese-Aging Process
articles.snippet: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has prompted an uproar among artisanal cheese makers and some consumers.
articles.abstract: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has prompted an uproar among artisanal cheese makers and some consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has produced a stink that rivals Limburger, prompting an uproar among the artisanal cheese makers and consumers who fear they might lose access to products like obscure blue cheeses from Vermont and imported Parmigiano-Reggiano.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Kim Severson

articles.headline: Bank of America Mortgage Settlement Is Said to Be Deadlocked
articles.snippet: The bank made its final multibillion-dollar settlement offer Monday, but it was said to be short of what the Justice Department wants it to pay for its role in the mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: The bank made its final multibillion-dollar settlement offer Monday, but it was said to be short of what the Justice Department wants it to pay for its role in the mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement deal, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank’s role at the center of the mortgage crisis.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Exhausted and Bereft, Iraqi Soldiers Quit Fight
articles.snippet: More soldiers are deserting the Iraqi Army, turning the tide of the war and fragmenting an institution that was supposed to provide a common sense of citizenship.
articles.abstract: More soldiers are deserting the Iraqi Army, turning the tide of the war and fragmenting an institution that was supposed to provide a common sense of citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The infantryman and his colleagues were already worn down after six months of fighting militants in western Iraq, men flush with weapons and zeal. Army commanders had no answer for the daily deadly ambushes and no broader strategy for prevailing in the longer war.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Suadad Al-Salhy

articles.headline: Cantor’s Loss a Bad Omen for Moderates
articles.snippet: Conservatives who have fueled showdowns on issues like immigration and raising the federal debt ceiling are likely to be emboldened by Eric Cantor’s shocking defeat.
articles.abstract: Conservatives who have fueled showdowns on issues like immigration and raising the federal debt ceiling are likely to be emboldened by Eric Cantor’s shocking defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership, so solid in its opposition to President Obama, was torn apart Tuesday by the defeat of its most influential conservative voice, Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader. His demise will reverberate all the way to the speaker’s chair, pull the top echelons of the House even further to the right and most likely doom any ambitious legislation, possibly through the next presidential election.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
articles.snippet: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.
articles.abstract: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants consolidated and extended their control over northern Iraq on Wednesday, seizing Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein, threatening the strategic oil refining town of Baiji and pushing south toward Baghdad, their ultimate target, Iraqi sources said.
articles.byline: By Suadad Al-Salhy and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Tax Breaks for Apple and Starbucks Investigated by E.U.
articles.snippet: The European Union has begun an investigation into how low-tax nations like Ireland have helped large multinationals like Apple and Starbucks reduce their tax bills by billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The European Union has begun an investigation into how low-tax nations like Ireland have helped large multinationals like Apple and Starbucks reduce their tax bills by billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials have been pushing some countries to plug corporate tax loopholes for years to help bolster government coffers in an era of shrinking public budgets and weak economic growth.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: An Artist Fills Galleries With Emptiness
articles.snippet: In Marina Abramovic’s latest show, at the Serpentine Gallery in London, nothing is everything.
articles.abstract: In Marina Abramovic’s latest show, at the Serpentine Gallery in London, nothing is everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — “You look suspicious,” Marina Abramovic said to an older couple standing to the side of a room in the Serpentine Gallery here on Thursday. The couple looked, well, suspicious, as around them people contemplated panels of bright primary colors, or lay on the floor, eyes closed. Ms. Abramovic took them by the hand, gently asked them to close their eyes, and led them away, walking with a slow, measured tread.

articles.headline: Banks Fear Missing Collateral in China
articles.snippet: The authorities are investigating loans based on collateral of metals at a Chinese port, with implications for Western banks and the Chinese credit market.
articles.abstract: The authorities are investigating loans based on collateral of metals at a Chinese port, with implications for Western banks and the Chinese credit market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Large banks and trading firms are frantically trying to determine whether they have fallen victim to a suspected commodities fraud emanating from the giant Qingdao Port in northeast China.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Neil Gough

articles.headline: Once Snubbed, David Brat Turns the Tables
articles.snippet: Mr. Brat’s ability to connect with voters and the perception that Eric Cantor was not engaged in his district combined to deliver one of the most stunning upsets in modern political history.
articles.abstract: Mr. Brat’s ability to connect with voters and the perception that Eric Cantor was not engaged in his district combined to deliver one of the most stunning upsets in modern political history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, David Brat, a conservative economics professor, decided to have a go at politics, making a run for a seat in the Virginia House of Delegates. But the back-room deal makers of his Republican Party snubbed him for someone chosen by allies of Representative Eric Cantor, the majority leader.
